66232.title: Five Madrid Ones (II)
66232.credit_line: Indianapolis Museum of Art, The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection: Fifty Works for Fifty States, a joint initiative of the Trustees of the Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection and the National Gallery of Art, with generous support of the National Endowment for the Arts and the Institute of Museum and Library Services
66232.provenance: Dorothy and Herbert Vogel, New York; given to the National Gallery of Art probably 1991-1992; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2008 through the national gift program The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection: Fifty Works for Fifty States, organized by the National Gallery of Art, the National Endowment for the Arts, and the Institute of Museum and Library Services.

extended_text.content: To create this group of subtle abstract drawings, Richard Tuttle deliberately selected the lowest grade of paper he could find during a visit to Madrid. These fragile drawings, whose delicate pencil markings are as tenuous as the paper on which they sit, have been stored since the late 1970s in this book handmade by the artist. Faint outlines can be seen on the higher quality book paper, where the low grade newsprint has discolored the paper around it. Also visible are the artist’s notations of the order of the drawings and a number corresponding to Dorothy Vogel’s system for cataloguing the works.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

66232.exhibit_history:
Forefront exhibition, Dec. 12, 2008-April 12, 2009
Collected Thoughts: Works from the Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection

66233.title: Five Madrid Ones (III)
66233.credit_line: Indianapolis Museum of Art, The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection: Fifty Works for Fifty States, a joint initiative of the Trustees of the Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection and the National Gallery of Art, with generous support of the National Endowment for the Arts and the Institute of Museum and Library Services
66233.provenance: Dorothy and Herbert Vogel, New York; given to the National Gallery of Art probably 1991-1992; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2008 through the national gift program The Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection: Fifty Works for Fifty States, organized by the National Gallery of Art, the National Endowment for the Arts, and the Institute of Museum and Library Services.

extended_text.content: To create this group of subtle abstract drawings, Richard Tuttle deliberately selected the lowest grade of paper he could find during a visit to Madrid. These fragile drawings, whose delicate pencil markings are as tenuous as the paper on which they sit, have been stored since the late 1970s in this book handmade by the artist. Faint outlines can be seen on the higher quality book paper, where the low grade newsprint has discolored the paper around it. Also visible are the artist’s notations of the order of the drawings and a number corresponding to Dorothy Vogel’s system for cataloguing the works.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

66233.exhibit_history:
Forefront exhibition, Dec. 12, 2008-April 12, 2009
Collected Thoughts: Works from the Dorothy and Herbert Vogel Collection

1447.title: baby dress

25998.title: sampler
25998.description: Colors- tan, beige, green, light blue, browns, dark greens, yellows, purple.  Alphabets- print stylized- 3 crowns at end of alphabet.  numbers are done in red.  Only half of material is worked.  Bottom part plain- except for very small birds, crowns, and a table and chair at very bottom.
25998.provenance: Ada F. Matthe; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (October 17, 1944).

7172.title: sampler
7172.description: Has a cross-stitched wreath and a flower basket and other small designs near the bottom.  Center alphabets were not finished.
7172.provenance: Ada F. Matthe; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (October 17, 1944).

1895.title: handkerchief (lace)

64925.title: Rhinoceros
64925.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in memory of Mrs. H. L. Conant
64925.provenance: Auction sale: Rachel Davis, Cleveland, OH; Dr. Steven Conant, Indianapolis, IN, by purchase; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2007.
64925.inscription:
inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: 11-25
signed and dated in pencil, below image, L.R.: Peterdi 1934
rights: © The Estate of Gabor F. Peterdi

extended_text.content:
Rhinoceros is among the first five prints created by Peterdi at Atelier 17. They were all line engravings, which was the medium the print workshop was intent on reviving after more than a century of artistic disfavor.

Peterdi’s Rhinoceros, whose hind legs have transformed into chaos, is in line with Surrealism, whose leading practitioners in Paris—Salvador Dalí, Joan Miró, Raoul Ubac, and Yves Tanguy—all frequented Atelier 17 in the 1930s.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

64925.exhibit_history: "Gabor Peterdi", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 01/11/2013-01/05/2014
